result.heading: "A MAN MUST LOOK AT HIS LIFE AND THINK LUXURY

direction.raw_text: 1989 - DAY A majestic panorama of the lush green slopes that are the Columbian highlands.  A faint chopping sound IS HEARD and then another.  WHOOSH.  WHOOSH.  The view changes and tiny dots appear on the hillside vegetation.  WHOOSH.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: R We realize the dots are people.  Workers swinging long steel machetes in slow methodical rhythm.  WHOOSH.  WHOOSH.  WE SEE the South American Indian MEN clearly now.  Their tar stained teeth.  Their gaunt faces riddled with crow's feet.  Their jaws chewing away on huge wads of coca leaves as they collect the harvest.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Old rickety trucks carrying the huge green tractor-sized bales speed along the narrow road.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The bundles are undone and Columbian women separate out the leaves.  Tribes of underweight workers carry armload after armload of the harvest and ritualistically dump them into a gigantic cannibal pot which sits on top of a raging bonfire. The leaves are being boiled down and a huge plume of smoke streaks the sky.  Wizened Indios brave the heat and shovel ashes into the pot to cool the solution.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A primitive but enormous makeshift lab contains all the equipment.  The machinery.  The solutions.  The over-sized vats.  Dark-skinned bandoleros smoke cigarettes and sport automatic weapons at all the points of entry.  The coca is now a "basuco" paste and is being sent in for a wash.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: 1989 - DAY A conveyor belt pours out brick after brick of pure cocaine hydrochloride.  The bricks are wrapped, tied up, weighed, and stamped with a "P" before being thrown into duffel bags.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A small twin-engine Cessna is loaded with dozens of duffel bags and the plane takes off.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Cessna touches down.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: 1966 - DAY The worksite is busy.  George is amongst other workers, working a summer job.  As George is taking five, he looks across the sight to Fred, who is sweeping up debris.  A long way from being the boss.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: 1966 - DAY George stands in line to register for college, wearing his Brooks Brothers suit, bowtie, and freshly Bryllcreamed hair. The room is crowded and the line is long.  Bob Dylan's "Subterranean Homesick Blues" blares out of one of the kid's transistor radios.  George looks around the room.  He is uncomfortable.  He catches his reflection in the shiny glass partition and stops.  He doesn't like what he sees. Something is not right.  He looks like everyone else.  Same cookie-cutter hair, same cookie-cutter clothes, same cookie cutter faces.  He's a carbon copy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Next. It's George's turn but he doesn't hear it.  "Twenty years of schooling and they put you on a day shift."  The words hit him like a tone of bricks as he continues to stare at his own reflection.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I was standing there, and it was like the outside of me and the inside of me didn't match, you know?  And then I looked around the room and it hit me.  I saw my whole life.  Where I was gonna live, what type of car I'd drive, who my neighbors would be.  I saw it all and I didn't want it.  Not that life.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: 1966 - DAY George sits with Fred.  It's breaktime and Fred eats from a lunch box.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There's something out there for me, Dad. Something different.  Something free form, you know?  Something for me, and college just isn't it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's too bad.  You would have been the first one in the family.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I know.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Alright.  You want me to get your old job back?  Because I could, you know, I could put in that word.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, Dad.  I don't want to...I mean, I just don't want... It's obvious to Fred that his son doesn't want to be like him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What are you going to do?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm going to California.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: 1968 - DAY SUPERIMPOSE: MANHATTAN BEACH, CALIFORNIA 1968 George and Tuna, now 21-years old, struggle with their bags. Their new place is a tackily furnished, two-story apartment with small balconies and a view of the ocean.  As George and Tuna struggle with the bags, two California beauties appear on the balcony next door: BARBARA BUCKLEY, 20, and MARIA GONZALES, 21.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You guys need some help? George and Tuna share a look.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't know about you, but I think we're gonna like it here.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: 1968 - DAY SERIES OF SHOTS Barbara and Maria introduce George and Tuna around to the Manhattan Beach regulars.  They are immediately accepted despite their ill fitting shorts and Tuna's unhip black socks.  The beach scene is one big party.  Lots of beer, music, bikinis, and good times.  By the end of the day, George and Tuna have a hundred new friends.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: California was like nothing I'd ever experienced.  The people were liberated and independent and full of new ideas.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They used words like "right on," "groovy," and "solid."  The women are all beautiful and seemed to share the same occupation.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm a flight attendant.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm a flight attendant.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm a flight attendant. The weed comes out and is passed around.  Pipes.  Joints. Bongs.  In SLOW MOTION, Barbara takes a huge hit of grass, grabs George's face, french kissing him, and giving him a huge shotgun.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: 1968 - DAY George and Barbara are sleeping late.  Their bodies intertwined beneath the sheets.  A slam of the front door wakes them up.  It's Tuna.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hey, wake up.  Come on, you two lovebirds.  Hurry, I want to show you something. George and Barbara shake cobwebs out and stumble into the kitchen to find Tuna holding a brown paper shopping bag.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Figured it out.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Figured what out?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You know how we were wondering what we were going to do for money?  Being how we don't want to get jobs and whatnot? Well, check this out. Tuna takes the paper bag and empties its contents on the kitchen table.  It's a grey mound of stocky, seedy marijuana. Barbara examines the reefer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Tuna, this is crap.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I know it's not the greatest.  It's commercial.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's garbage.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's oregano.  You got ripped off, pal. What are you gonna do with all this?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We sell it.  I got it all figured out. We make three finger lids and sell them on the beach.  We move all of it.  We've made ourselves a hundred bucks.  Or a lot of weed for our head.  What do you think?  Not bad, huh?  I got the baggies and everything.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You can't sell this to your friends.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Man.  Fuck you guys.  I have this great idea and you guys have to be all skeptical.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Look, if you really wanna score some dope, I got the guy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: 1968 - DAY George, Barbara and Tuna stop outside the front door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Are you sure this guy is cool?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You'll see for yourself.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A beauty parlor for men?  Sounds pretty queer. They walk in.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: 1968 - CONTINUOUS George, Tuna and Barbara enter.  The Whipping Post is California's first male hair salon.  George looks around at the customer's being pampered.  Haircuts, pedicures, manicures.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Nothing like this back home.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Derek!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: is a curious man.  Daringly effeminate, especially for the sixties, he is always surrounded by beautiful women.  As he sees Barbara, he stops his haircut and runs to embrace her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Barbie! Derek's female entourage rush over as well.  Kisses all around.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So, this is the new man, huh?  He's cute! George and Tuna stick out there hands.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: George.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Tuna.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Tuna, oh my.  Enchante, George.  Barbie, he's yummy.  He looks like a Ken doll. Oooh, Ken and Barbie.  It's perfect. Alright, girls, give me five minutes. Derek makes dismissing gestures and the girls scatter.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Everyone, shoo!  You, too, Barbie.  I want to talk to the boys alone. After the girls leave, Derek closes the partition and his playful demeanor changes.  He's all business now.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What can I do for you guys?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We want some grass.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I know what you want.  But, first of all, are you cops?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Because if you are, you have to tell me. If not, it's entrapment.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We're not cops.  We're from Massachusettes.  I mean, does he look like a cop?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I guess not.  Okay.  You know, you're very lucky you're friends of Barbie's. If you weren't, I'd never talk to you. Derek pulls a television-sized brick of quality marijuana out from under a sink and sets it down in front of George.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What the fuck is that?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's your grass.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Wow.  That's more than we had in mind.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't nickel and dime.  You want it or not? George and Tuna look at each other.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We'll take it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Look what the cat dragged in.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Holy shit, Dulli.  What the hell are you doing here?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, I'll tell you.  I was walking down the beach, minding my business, when who did I see but this fucking guy.  I didn't know you guys were living in California.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah, but what are you doing out here?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm on vacation.  On my way back to school.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This calls for a joint.  You want to do the honors?

direction.raw_text: When there's something to move, it's too easy not to.  Do you know how many colleges are in a twenty mile radius? U. Mass, Amherst, B.U....
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Smith.  Hampshire....
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Right.  And Holyoke.  There are a hundred thousand rich kids with their parents' money to spend, but there's never anything available.  Nothing good, anyway.  I'm paying four hundred dollars for shit.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: 1968 - DAY Derek, George and Barbara sit around.  The blinds are drawn.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The way we figure it, Barbara flies to Boston twice a week.  Two bags per flight.  Twenty-five pounds in each bag.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're kidding, right?  That's a hundred pounds a week.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah, I know, it's a lot of weight.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We're gonna call it California sinsemilla.  Sounds exotic.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm telling you, Derek, it will sell.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't know...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Here's the best part.  We can charge five-hundred a pound.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Come on, George, no one is going to pay that.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's already been negotiated.  It's done.  The money is there waiting. Derek looks at Barbara.  She nods.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Goodness.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Goodness is right.  If you do the math, that's over thirty grand a week profit. I want you to be my partner on this, Derek.  Fifty-fifty.  That's fifteen thousand a week for you, my friend.  In your pocket, free and clear.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And I only deal with you?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Barbara and me.  No one else. Derek thinks about it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's gonna work, Derek.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't know.  East coast.  Airplanes. It all sounds pretty risky.

direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: 1968 - DAY A huge jet goes right to left through frame.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: 1968 - DAY Barbara is greeted by KEVIN DULLI with a hug.  A baggage claim check is slipped into Kevin's hand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Any message?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Keep it coming.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We see Barbara's two red Samsonites being taken off the belt by Kevin.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Same scene repeated, except different clothes on all.  Maybe Kevin is dressed a little better.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: More.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The same scene repeated, same things changed again; now Kevin is definitely dressed a little better.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I need more.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What do you want me to do?  I can only take two bags, and I can't fly back here everyday.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I know, but I've got a feeding frenzy on my hands.  Tell George this is small potatoes.  We're missing out on some serious cash.  You tell George.  He'll think of something.
direction.name: direction
